DOC.HEAD: South Warms a Bit; Cold Front Moves East from Plains
Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs, `Fog was ... valleys' with 4 grafs to ADD that fog delayed airline flights in Seattle, Salt Lake City. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `Temperatures were...
DOC.TEXT: Warmer weather was making a welcome return to the South today, and a cold front was moving east from the Plains, bringing more cold, dry weather. Mild, dry weather was expected across the West, and a cold front with a little rain or snow was forecast for the Pacific Northwest, where snow fell in Pendleton, Ore., this morning. In much of the South, where a Christmas weekend freeze burst water pipes in thousands of homes and businesses, overnight temperatures were at or near freezing. Temperatures today were forecast to rise to the 60s from Texas across Louisiana through Florida, and the 40s and 50s in the rest of the South. Miami's highs could reach 80 by the weekend, according to the National Weather Service. A cold high-pressure system moved east from Iowa today, followed by slightly warmer air. The front was expected to scatter freezing rain and light snow as it moved across the Ohio Valley and Great Lakes into New England. The front was expected to bring dry, sunny and cold weather to the Northeast today, with tempratures from near zero in far northern New England, rising to the 20s in New York City, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, and to the 30s in Maryland and Virginia. Fog returned this morning to Seattle and Salt Lake City, where heavy fog disrupted airline travel Tuesday. At Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, flights were diverted or delayed for nine hours Tuesday, causing a traffic snarl on nearby roads because stranded passengers' cars jammed all the garages. At Salt Lake City International Airport, some flights were diverted and others delayed up to an hour Tuesday, despite efforts at fog-dispersal _ a technique much like cloud-seeding that involves sprinkling dry ice, or carbon dioxide, from planes. Fog also was expected this morning in parts of Montana, Idaho and Utah, as well as in California's Sacramento and San Joaquin valleys. Temperatures were expected to rise to the 70s along the southern fringe of the desert Southwest, and the 50s in northern New Mexico, Arizona and California.
